Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Authorship Analysis in Cross-Domain Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Authorship Analysis (AA) is the task of extracting characteristics from written documents that can help to determine authorship of a document, generate a profile of the author, or identify cases of plagiarism. AA can be used for historical purposes, to settle disputes over the original creators of a given document, and to build a prosecution case against an online abuser.

Most previous work in AA assumes the availability of samples with known authorship that closely match the domain of the documents of interest. A strong assumption like this one limits the applications of AA approaches. This program addresses this key outstanding challenge by designing robust frameworks for scenarios with different cross-domain degrees: cross-topic, cross-genre and cross-modality (text vs. transcribed speech). The project leverages the large amounts of free text available representing each cross-domain setting to learn general lexical and syntactic distributional correspondences. These correspondences are used to map the out-of-domain texts to a representation that is closer to the target domain.

Direct contributions of this research include new approaches to extract and embed cross-domain prior knowledge into AA models in the form of distributional trajectories; and a solid understanding of the influence of topic, genre, and modality in the feature engineering process for AA that will also be helpful in other text processing tasks. This research will make direct contributions to the field of forensic linguistics, which is of major relevance for national security.

The PI will design an advanced seminar in computational approaches for forensic linguistics and will expand her ongoing educational and outreach activities for underrepresented groups in the STEM disciplines. The PI will integrate opportunities for international visits to key research labs for the graduate students involved in the program that will enrich their training and provide great networking opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the problem of modelling style in text in scenarios with different cross-domain degrees: from topic, to platform and genre. The application domains of the technology developed include authorship attribution and profiling, as well as style characterization in creative writing.

 

We developed important new resources, knowledge, and methods for style analysis of text. More specifically these are our contributions to intellectual merit:

  • Our research clarified the role of character n-grams in predicting authorship of a document, and in general, we found that style is better captured by computational models that differentiate character n-grams by their lexico-syntactic role in the text. This finding was later shown by us to also apply in other tasks were style is relevant.
  • We also achieved key contributions at the intersection of domain adaptation and style modelling. We propose relevant new features to do structural correspondence learning in authorship attribution. Since no other work using correspondence learning has tackled authorship attribution, there was no knowledge as to what types of features would be good to use as pivot features. This is a major finding since pivot features are the core of the algorithm. We proposed a new binarization approach to the pivot features based on the median value. This new binarization achieves better results than the original model. We showed empirically that by using only the new low dimensional features we obtain higher accuracy then by including the original non-pivot features. This finding is relevant for any other task using structural correspondence learning since no other previous work has shown that dropping the original features from the representation of the source domain instances was a possibility that would improve results. 
  • We extended our research on modelling style to tasks were style can make important contributions to prediction performance of automatic models. In particular, we explored the use of style in tasks such as named entity recognition in social media, predicting likeability of books, and in high level story characterization.  Our research shows that style in text can be very broadly modeled as a combination of a wide set of characteristics that include shape and punctuation, but also special characters such as emoticons in social media data. We found that in creative writing, emotion flows can also be a strong discriminative feature of the writing style of an author.
  • We also contributed a new multichannel Convolutional Neural Network architecture that successfully combines style with topic information to improve prediction accuracy. More relevant to the goals of this project, this deep learning architecture showed to generalize well across different genres (amazon product reviews, Twitter data and health forum posts), which shows the domain independence capability of the proposed model.
  • We also develop and released to the community a new resource to support research in the space of style and high-level story characterization. This new data set contains around ~15K movie plot synopsis and their associated tags. The tags are a combination of style, emotional landscape and genre. This new dataset can be leveraged by the research community to advance state of the art in language understanding and style modelling in creative writing. We have received requests for the dataset from close to 700 researchers, and expect the potential impact of the resource to continue to grow as awareness of this dataset spreads in the community.

 

With respect to broader impact, this project supported the training of several graduate students, including one female PhD student that has joined a top tech company as a research scientist. Several undergraduate students were also supported to pursue research under this project, two of them from underrepresented groups in STEM. These students received training on natural language processing techniques, as well as mentorship by the PI and her group of graduate students. Lastly, the PI had the opportunity to explore her research interests in computational modelling of style. The project provided the needed resources to support graduate and undergraduate students to collaborate with her on this, as well as travel funds to present research results at top venues in her field.
